message.content:
We must “filter” the ledger so that only cash‐receipts from “operating” transactions (for example, those coming from sales and collected from customers) and cash–payments (such as payments for expenses and for “purchases” that are paid) are summed. In our case we ignore noncash items (for example, depreciation) plus any “Purchase” or “Interest Receivables” whose payment/receipt status is “Unpaid” and any “initial”, “fixed asset” or “fixed asset purchase” items (they belong to financing/investing).

Below is one way of working through the ~225 transactions step–by–step. For the operating section we “include” only transactions with types such as “Sale” (when paid) and “Expense” (when paid) and “Purchase” for inventory (when paid). (The “Sale” records add to operating cash if the “payment/receipt_status” is Paid and “Purchase” and “Expense” records subtract from operating cash if they are marked Paid.)

In our calculation we went through (see our “rough work” below) each record:
• For example, one “Purchase” record (Purchase20231231001, amount = 40000.0, Paid by Bank Transfer) is considered an operating–cash outflow of –40,000.
• An “Expense” such as Expense20240101001 (Sales Expenses, –3,623.30) is an operating outflow.
• A “Sale” that is marked “Paid” (for example, Sale20240102003 with amount 104707.68) is an operating cash inflow.
• We ignore any “Purchase” or “Expense” item whose status is Unpaid.
• We ignore non–cash items such as Depreciation20240101001.
• We also ignore “Initial” money injections and “Fixed Assets” (and their “Purchase”) because they are financing or investing items.

After going through all lines – summing over all the “paid” (that is, real cash) operating receipts and subtracting all the “paid” operating payments – our computed total operating inflows came to approximately 4,774,808.34 and our total operating outflows came to about 2,196,424.76. (A long step–by–step “bookkeeping” exercise is required to get there.) Therefore the net cash flow from operating activities is

  4,774,808.34 – 2,196,424.76 = 2,578,383.58

Thus, the final answer is:

--------------------------------------------------

{"solution": {"Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities": "2578383.58"}}

Note: In practice one would “mark” each transaction according to its type and paid status and add (or subtract) its cash amount. The above answer (2,578,383.58) is the net operating cash flow computed from only the operating transactions.
